perturbation.original_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.changed_text: All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System (“Confidential Information”) is deemed confidential, except for information the Member believes to be already known by the public.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines 'Confidential Information' with specific exceptions, aligning with trade secret laws. The modified text replaces objective criteria ('came to Member’s attention by lawful means prior to disclosure,' 'part of the public domain') with a subjective standard ('Member believes to be already known by the public'). This creates ambiguity and contradicts established legal definitions of trade secrets, making enforcement difficult. A member could claim they 'believed' something was public knowledge, regardless of whether it truly was, weakening the protection of confidential information.

perturbation.original_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
perturbation.changed_text: (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Similar Business that is, or intends to operate, within a reasonable distance of the premises of your Franchised Business or within a reasonable distance of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System.
perturbation.explanation: The original text uses 'Competitive Business' and defines a three-mile radius non-compete zone, which, while potentially subject to scrutiny, provides a clear, objective standard. The modified text replaces 'Competitive Business' with the vague term 'Similar Business' and the defined three-mile radius with 'reasonable distance.' This introduces significant ambiguity. What constitutes a 'similar business' and a 'reasonable distance' is open to interpretation and legal challenge, contradicting the need for clear and enforceable terms in non-compete agreements. This weakens the enforceability of the non-compete clause.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State laws governing non-compete agreements (e.g., California Business and Professions Code Section 16600, which disfavors non-competes)

perturbation.original_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.changed_text: (d) As used in this Agreement, the term “Post-Term Period” shall mean a period deemed appropriate by the Franchisor following: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member’s employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).
perturbation.explanation: The original text clearly defines the 'Post-Term Period' as a two-year period, providing certainty and predictability. The modified text replaces this with a period 'deemed appropriate by the Franchisor.' This gives the Franchisor complete discretion to determine the length of the non-compete period, which is likely unenforceable and contradicts the principles of fair contracting. Courts generally require non-compete agreements to have reasonable timeframes. Giving one party unilateral control over the duration creates an unreasonable and potentially oppressive term, making it unlikely to be upheld.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract law principles of reasonableness and fairness; state laws governing non-compete enforceability.
